captions.text:
This thing is so fast at speed and G-forces
that you have to remember to breath, you have

to remember to hold on, and you have to remember
where you're pointing it. It's absolutely

insane. The new Corvette Z06 is the most powerful
car GM has produced. In a sense a space once

taken up by the ZL1. The performance numbers
are hard to belief but you can take the top

off and order as an automatic. How is that
even possible? Here we have the new Corvette

Z06 looks like fun! And of course we have
gone on and Chevy's gone on about how great

the 8 gear is but they gave us a 7-speed manual
so that's what we'll test. This is stage 2

of 3 aerodynamic kit and these are parts we'll
talk about once I get to the splitter and

this side over here. Down here at the from
this is the splitter but there are actually

2 brakes inlets that lead to the brakes and
let cool air in. All the aerodynamic stuff

here is functional by a large amount. These
2 guys you see here they're not a design choice

they're there to pass a pedestrian safety
standard in Europe that's why they had to

do these little shark's teeth coming out there.
Here's where we get to the meat of the car

this is the ZL7 package of the Z06 that means
there's a bunch of different upgrade performance

parts in the tires and carbon ceramic brakes.
the tires themselves are Michelin Pilot Sport

Cup 2s and they are really, really sticky.
We've used a bit of tread already. Further

back we have these side skirts and this guy
here a cooling feeding duct. These feed the

motor its a combination of a naccaduct and
a ram air effect. At one point there's a nacca

air duct effect and a ram air effect on the
other side. They actually made this in the

wind tunnel and when the engineers saw it
they didn't know what to think of it, but

they tested it and that's why it sits here
the way it does. This is the supercharged

6.2 Liter LT-4 V8 that makes 650 horsepower
and 650 pound feet of torque. Why is this

engine incredible? Well the power and torque
also it's a pushrod engine that has activation

its amazing technology. Wondering why aren't
they doing a quad cab engine and such? IF

you look at the engine and see that having
the cam in the block you don't have a bunch

of crazy valve train to get in the way of
other things. It means keeping a low roofline.

Having a compact engine means a low hoodline
that means great visibility. The advantages

are numorous and the engine is rich. Interestingly
Chevy originally wanted to do a big displacement

high rev engine that won emissions targets
but this is what they went with and it looks

pretty awesome. The hardware looks great.
Next we'll see it on the test track. Launch

control makes applying the 650 pound feet
on tap more consistent but also slower. Find

the right amount of tread and you'll reach
60 in 3.2 seconds and the quarter mile in

11.3 seconds at 126.2 miles per hour. Peak
stopping distance of 91 feet from 60 miles

per hour is low as the last ZR1 and as our
test dates stay under 100 feet. The ZL6 22

second lap time around the figure 8 is the
fastest we've ever recorded from a production

car that wasn't the Porsche 918. The 918 is
better. The 1.16 average lateral acceleration

is the greatest we've seen from something
that wasn't a race car. It felt like driving

a tilt o whirl. The car is very fast! Listen
to that. And this is amazing. I want to call

it a Z-51 because it reminds me of it in the
good ways. I remember the first time I drove

the Z-51 I got in the car, put it in gear
and wanted to void my bowels! Ridiculous and

scary and everything. So much fun to lay on
the throttle but what impresses me most is

G-forces when you press on the gas back in
the seat or the sides when you go around a

corner. All you need to do is think of the
Z-51 and turn the dial up more. It drives

similar to the Z-51 only we're going so much
more faster. One of the traits from the Z-51

was fear it was a sketchy car to drive quickly
you felt fear brining it up to speed because

it was so fast. This doesn't have that fear
this doesn't give you worry. You can jump

in and instead of feeling threatened you can
enjoy it more instead. First impressions of

this thing are pretty awesome this offers
a performance value. So far not many down

sides. Incredible performance for not a ton
of money. It's kind of nuts. Pro Racer Randy

Pobst joined us to do hot laps but of course
he got it the fastest way you can get it with

a Stage 3 Aero package and the automatic.
After driving it hard you get out of the Z06

quiet and wide eyed. There's a level of performance
few cars can attain and those that do have

way high price tags. This Corvette just over
$80,000 to start and about $100,000 as tested

and with that price comes a clear message:
bring it on, world! I'm kind of hungry so

I'll buy a fast food chain. You know? I kind
of feel like buying an RC airplane so I'll

get an F18 hornet. It's great but my god!
It's so much! Oh my god, and the performance
is off the charts.

comments.author: bikinchris

comments.text:
What you want in an engine is a flat torque curve in a broad band. The 
before mentioned engines might make less torque, but what is the power 
band? Does it peak and fall off quickly? Does it stay flat for a large part 
of the rpm's? Maximum torque numbers by themselves do not mean a whole lot. 
Unless we have a graph of all of these engines, we cannot tell a whole lot. 
 Race engines make lots of power because of high rpm's. That being said, 
torque can be multiplied by gearing if you have enough rpm's to do 
something with it. Building torque (and keeping it) at high rpm's requires 
good breathing. Having the 4 valves and the accuracy of the OHC can help 
that a whole lot.

You keep asking for me to do things for you when you only answer questions 
you like to answer. Also, quit cursing. it undermines the power of your 
opinion.  You have legitimate questions and opinions. Don't take away from 
them with profanity.

Have you written to GM yet to make all of their engine pushrod engines 
again? Also, if Chevy comes out with a great DOHC V8 engine, what are you 
going to say?
comments.author: Chris Daigle

comments.text:
+bikinchris You getting butthurt about it is not the same thing as 
presenting a good argument. Why don't you cry more instead of doing what I 
asked you to do?

It's very simple. You are claiming other manufacturers like Ferrari or 
Porsche make more efficient engines, citing HP/liter as the ONLY METRIC to 
support that opinion. But since al the engines you mentioned make LESS 
TORQUE than Chevy's pushrod V8, how are they more efficient? How are they 
more efficient by making LESS TORQUE? In what way does having less torque 
make them more efficient, in your mind? Explain it to us, because it defies 
logic.
comments.author: Vernon Price

comments.text:
+Vernon Price Thank you. I stand corrected. Obviously, the 6.2L makes 30mpg 
while it is providing 400+ftlb of torque. Of course everyone racing is 
missing out by not swapping to the Chevy engine. While you are at it, make 
sure you write to Chevy and tell them to go back to pushrods on every 4 and 
6 cylinder in all GM products. Maybe they will get more torque out of there 
engines?
comments.author: bikinchris

comments.text:
+bikinchris Yeah and you're still not getting it. I'll say it again, and 
this is the second or third time now - this argument is about EFFICIENCY. 
The argument you are trying to make is that the Porsche engine is more 
EFFICIENT by using HP/liter as an argument.

I'm informing you that by leaving out the TORQUE numbers in your 
comparison, you are proving yourself to be an idiot that doesn't understand 
how displacement or efficiency in general works. 

And by the way I've gotten 30 MPG in a Stingray in 8 cylinder mode too. I'm 
still waiting for you or anybody else to do what I ASKED you to do: Show me 
an engine that makes more than 460 HP AND TORQUE NA - don't forget about 
the torque - in an 8 cylinder engine that is less than 6.2 liters AND gets 
30 MPG.

Until you can do that, you have absolutely no leg to stand on regarding 
engine efficiency. Your whining about whether torque is useful or not is 
irrelevant. Do what I asked you to do.
comments.author: Vernon Price

comments.text:
+Vernon Price You missed something "And ALL of these cars are faster than 
the Corvette." Stump pulling. Is not common in road racing. And the 4 
cylinder trick used to get more mileage is neat, but doesn't count when 
getting maximum torque does it?
comments.author: bikinchris

comments.text:
+bikinchris "Porsche 918 gas engine makes 608hp out of 4.6L V8 engine."

...and only 398 lb-ft of torque. Have you just not been paying attention to 
this conversation at all? 

"Ariel Atom makes 500hp in a V8 engine that weighs 200lb, less than half of 
the pushrod Chevy engine"

...and only 284 lb-ft of torque. Are you seeing a pattern yet?

Both those examples make LESS TORQUE than the LT1 in the Corvette. You're 
going to have to try again son, and this time don't forget about the 
torque. 

And the two cars you used as an example, one is a million dollar supercar, 
and the other is a barely street legal racing cage with wheels. And your 
argument is that they're faster on a  track than a Corvette? Really? You 
feel the need to compare a million dollar supercar to the Z06 to try to 
make the point that the Porsche is faster? While conveniently forgetting to 
mention the Porsche costs 10 times as much money?

Are you an idiot? 

Also this is about efficiency. You are claiming engines like the Porsche's 
gas engine are more efficient because it makes more HP with less 
displacement. But it also makes less TORQUE so how is it more efficient 
again?

Saying the LT1 is less efficient while it both A) gets better MPG and B) 
makes more torque is laughably ignorant on your part.

comments.text:
+bikinchris Of course, I am sure you will want to move the goal posts again 
and claim something else is much more important to fast cars than 
horsepower per pound and high rpm.

makes 608hp out of 4.6L V8 engine. The Hartley engine used in the Ariel

comments.author: bikinchris

comments.text:
+Chris Daigle Really? Again with Ferrari's 6.2 liter NA engine making over 
700 HP? How many times to I have to tell you that's a V12, not a V8? How 
stupid do you have to be to continue to compare a V12 to a V8?

Oh and if you're trying to suggest that Ferrari could build a V8 with 775 
NA HP, why haven't they done that? Because apparently they need 4 more 
cylinders to accomplish what you are suggesting Ferrari's level of engine 
efficiency can accomplish with 8. Do you understand how badly you fucked 
that up?

Not only did you just disprove your own statement on how efficient 
Ferrari's engines are, you did it by suggesting Ferrari could make a V8 
that makes more NA HP than their own V12. 

Are you just a moron? Is that what the problem is?

Oh and you suggested going from pushrods to OHC would raise the engine "an 
inch". Jesus fucking christ. Well at least you've proven your complete and 
total ignorance of how engines work. 

You said "bigger engines means more powers". So you're talking about 
torque, right?Because that's what displacement gets you. See Ferrari's 
engines as a perfect example of that. I'm still waiting for you to show me 
an example of a Ferrari engine that makes more NA torque with less 
displacement than the LT1 does. Will you be doing that any time soon? I'd 
love to see you actually back up your argument with facts. 

And no, Chevy is not using pushrods because it saves money. Try again. And 
I'm not defending Chevy so much as I am correcting you. This isn't about 
me, it's about you being wrong. If you disagree, do what I asked you to do. 
Show me that Ferrari engine, because obviously you aren't learning anything 
from that book about competition engine building.
comments.author: Vernon Price

comments.text:
+Vernon Price You still don't understand. I have been writing 
about efficiency. How much power per cu in. If the 6.2L engine in the 
Corvette was putting out the power of the Ferrari per liter, the naturally 
aspirated engine would be putting out  775hp and 523 lbft of torque and you 
and every writer in the industry would be crowing about the newest 
unbeatable supercar of all time. Probably comparable to the V8 Ariel Atom. 
Then they would supercharge it for probably 1000 hp and 800+lbft of torque, 
making the Corvette even more unbeatable. And it would raise the hood about 
an inch in a small area and make the fender walls a few inches wider on 
either side. Big deal. OF COURSE it would burn more fuel. More power 
requires it.
Bigger engines means more power and that was the reason for my post in the 
first place. Except an engine that makes more power per cu in, makes even 
more when it's bigger.
I know why Chevy uses pushrods. Simply put, Chevy uses pushrods because it 
saves money. An overhead cam engine designed from the ground up would cost 
many millions to design and build. Since the days of the V8 in the US are 
probably numbered and after a few years only the most expensive cars will 
use a V8, making the money needed to redesign the V8 a bad idea, unless 
forced to do so by emissions regulations or something.
As for books, the kind I read are things like "The Design and Tuning of 
Competition Engines" by Phillip Smith. As well as books on suspension 
tuning and other automotive titles.
Bottom line? It is clear that you will defend Chevy to the death and I 
refuse to believe like you do. We are going to have to agree to disagree.
comments.author: Chris Daigle

comments.text:
+Chris Daigle Your point was about efficiency, not the reasons people buy a 
car. The Corvette gets better MPG out of a larger engine. It's pretty 
fucking simple to understand. You can try to deflect that fact if you want, 
but it's not helping you make a case for efficiency. 

And you had been talking about how Ferrari engines are better while 
neglecting to mention the fact that they make less torque, which I think is 
an oversight on your part. I asked you to show me any other engine that 
does what the LT1 does, and you obviously couldn't do it. So apparently not 
even Ferrari are smart enough to make a V8 that has EQUAL torque and HP 
with both numbers being 460 or higher, while also getting 30 mpg. 

How is torque per liter relevant when the number is less overall? If 
hp/liter is the most important factor why isn't the S2000 the fastest car 
on earth? Using engine efficiency as an argument is beyond stupid. 

And once again, there are specific reasons Chevy is using a pushrod V8. Are 
you suggesting they don't know how to build an OHC V8, and that's the 
reason they're using pushrods? It kind of sounds like that's what you're 
suggesting. If you still don't understand why Chevy is using a pushrod V8, 
then I don't know what to tell you. Read a fucking book, maybe? Educate 
yourself?
comments.author: Vernon Price

comments.text:
+Vernon Price Thanks for proving my point. You claim the 6.2L makes 480 
lbft of torque, which is 77.4 lbft per liter and the Ferrari engine makes 
84.4 lbft of torque per liter. More efficient.
And yes, more horsepower makes worse mileage usually. More power requires 
more fuel. Does ANYONE buy the Corvette for better mileage?
At least it has a nice truck engine. Chevy has done an admirable job of 
improving the small block over the decades. One great idea was to lose the 
Siamese port configuration.
I just can't wait to hear what the vociferous backers of the pushrod 
engines say when Chevy builds an OHC V8. They build DOHC 4 cylinders and 6 
cylinder engines.
comments.author: Chris Daigle

comments.text:
+Chris Daigle OH yeah, everybody likes to talk about horsepower efficiency 
while forgetting about torque. The Ferrari 458, 560 HP from a 4.5 liter V8, 
so efficient! Oh but it only makes 380 lb-ft of torque. LOL? So how is 4 
valves helping when it makes 100 less lb-ft of torque and gets worse MPG?

So I'll add another challenge to what I said above. Can you name any other 
engine that is 6.2 liters or larger, makes 460 HP AND TORQUE or more, is 8 
cylinders or more, and gets 30 mpg?

Right. Torque is what you get with displacement, and not even Ferrari can 
change the laws of physics. The Mustang you mentioned makes 60 less lb-ft 
of torque and that's just at peak which is higher than it is in the LT1. In 
other words the LT1 not only makes more torque across the entire power 
band, it makes MUCH more torque on the low and midrange, and it's still 60 
more than the Mustang at peak. AND it gets 30 MPG. And it makes more power 
earlier with more under the curve.

You have to wind the Mustang's engine out to get the HP out of it. The LT1 
has power everywhere.

Oh and that Ferrari 6.2 liter engine? You neglected to mention that it's a 
V12. Don't be a fucking idiot, please. 

And yes, if I designed an engine for the Corvette, which has a very low 
hood, I would use a pushrod engine for the same reasons Chevy does. Their 
6.2 liter V8 is more physically compact than the 5 liter engine in the 
Mustang, for that reason. It's lighter, too. When you don't have that 
entire overhead valvetrain it saves a lot of space.
comments.author: Vernon Price

comments.text:
Efficient? As in how much horsepower per cubic inch and how reliable it is. 
I know the 6.2l engine in the Vette is VERY reliable. But there are engines 
much smaller that make close to the same horsepower reliably. The Mustang 
has an engine based on one that has lasted a million miles in taxi use and 
is a whole liter point two smaller, yet makes almost the same power. in a 
car as light as the Vette with a 7 speed and high gearing, it would 
probably make very close to the same mileage. Highway fuel economy is not 
just determined by the engine. It has a lot to do with aerodynamics and 
weight. Ferrari had a 6.2L engine with 731 horsepower (117hp/L) with NO 
supercharger. The Ferrari 458's V8 develops an even more impressive 562 
horsepower from 4.5 liters (125hp/L). THAT'S why 4 valves helps. That's why 
the Ford 427 SOHC engine was outlawed by NASCAR before it could turn a 
wheel. (even though it only had two valves per cylinder) Chevy was building 
their own version of an overhead cam big block for NASCAR when Ford got the 
ax. THAT'S why overhead cams are worth the trouble and money.

Be honest. If you had a blank sheet of paper and were asked to design an 
engine for THE flagship of Chevrolet, how would you design it? Would you 
really build a pushrod engine or a DOHC engine?
comments.author: Chris Daigle

comments.text:
+Chris Daigle Efficient how, exactly? Let me put it to you this way: Can 
you name any other engine that is 6.2 liters or larger, makes 460 HP or 
more, is 8 cylinders or more, and gets 30 mpg?

Why is having 4 valves per cylinder relevant again? Oh right, it's not. You 
understand that the LT1 also has direct injection and variable valve 
timing, right? So what's the problem?

Also don't compare street cars to F1 cars. Come on. Be at least somewhat 
realistic.
comments.author: Vernon Price

comments.text:
Again, I was not referring to whether OHC or pushrods were newer

continuing to use pushrod engines are legitimate ignores all of the engines

value a lower center of gravity?

comments.text:

Are those the "reasons" you were talking about? Because those are the main 
reasons they're still using pushrods. You saying those reasons are bogus 
just makes you look ignorant.

has better straight line grip, but it's still slower around a track than 
the Z06. it also has less lateral grip, brakes worse and accelerates slower 
than the Z06. It also has less HP and torque. It also gets worse MPG. It 
also weighs more. I'm not sure where you're getting "better" from.

The GT-R's engine needs to be hand built because it's so high strung. GM's 
LS engines and the new LT engines are as reliable as the day is long, 
because they're not overworked. They easily make huge amounts of HP and 
will do it to the track, on the track, and back home, for years and years. 
The LS motors are legendary for their reliability, that's why the LS is the 
motor everybody swaps into their project cars. 

The GT-R's engine is vastly more expensive and it's much more delicate and 
high strung. if anything goes out of whack with the GT-R's  motor, it's 
toast. That's not "better".

comments.text:
+BTD37 Actually I didn't say traction didn't have anything to do with 
performance. I said nothing even remotely similar to that. I said 0-60 is a 
measurement of traction, not performance. Because it is. 0-60 times are 
completely, 100% dependent on traction. Are you denying that? This is a 
stupidity test, so answer carefully.

And calling me the moron here while being unable to spell "you're" is not 
very convincing, son. You're the one who tried to use 0-60 as a valid 
metric of performance while using an AWD car vs. a RWD car, apparently 
without understanding that of course the AWD car is going to be faster in a 
0-60 test. That would make you the moron, not me. 

And yes, in this one solitary isolated video, the GTPR won. And it was 
discovered later that the GT-R won because the Z06 had an alignment 
problem. Which would explain why this one test is the only time a GT-R has 
ever been able to beat the Z06. You remember the VIR times, right? Would 
you care to explain those, if the GT-R is faster? Hmm? 8 seconds a lap 
slower is the opposite of faster.

You want to talk about ignoring the facts, there you go. I don't care that 
you don't LIKE the results, the results are still the results. If you want 
to cry about it, do it on your own time. 

And even after I had to explain to you why the GT-R is faster 0-60 (hint - 
it's traction, not power... obviously) you mentioned it AGAIN. Do you have 
a learning disability? Is that the problem? And here's an example of 1/4 
mile:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LcHcIF6qDNI

Note that this was a stock Z06 on STREET TIRES not drag radials, so it was 
still having traction issues. And it was also a MANUAL which is slower than 
the auto in the 1/4 mile. And finally, look at the trap speed - 127 is 
still faster than any GT-R ever made. Stock Z06s that can get traction off 
the line, usually with drag radials, are hitting 130 MPH traps and 10.6 
ETs. If you don't understand how traction helps RWD cars get better ETs and 
trap speeds, then you need to go back to school.

And to correct your misconception, the GT-R beat the Z06 around ONE track 
during ONE test, when the Z06 had a bad alignment. The Z06 has beaten the 
GT-R around many other tracks. VIR is just the most obvious example.

comments.text:
+BTD37 Anybody who wants to know what the car is capable of cares about 
every test that is run on these cars. The figure 8 indicates how well it 
handles. Which is better than the GT-R. It can get through more turns 
faster than the GT-R can. If I have to explain why you want better braking 
you may be an idiot. 

You seem to have ignored all the points I made last post. Is there any 
particular reason for that? Did you miss the part about the alignment being 
off in this one test that you keep referring to? Do you not understand why 
that is significant? Has it never occurred to you that the nismo has never 
beaten the Z06 in any other test? Have you ever considered that there might 
be a reason for that? Did you not understand the part about the Z06 putting 
down a lap time at VIR that was 8 seconds faster than the nismo GT-R? And 
by the way 8 seconds is a lot more than the ~1 second the nismo beat the 
Z06 by in this one test you're referring to.

Is there any particular reason I have to keep going over what I already 
told you?

Also, I already know you're a moron. You know how I know that? Because you 
brought up 0-60 times. Do you understand the main factor in getting a good 
0-60 time? It's traction. What is the GT-R's one advantage over the Z06?

Traction. Do you see where this is going? All AWD cars have artificially 
high 0-60 times because they don't have traction issues off the line. The 
Z06 has traction issues past 60 MPH, because it's putting so much HP to the 
ground through just the rear wheels that the tires can't hold traction.

So you referring to 0-60 times is an indicator that you don't understand 
that 0-60 is a measurement of traction, not performance. You know how you 
get around that? You do a 5-60 test, it's an acceleration test from a 
rolling idle. When you eliminate the nismo GT-R's AWD traction advantage, 
you know what happens?

Nismo GT-R 5-60: 3.9 seconds
Z06 5-60: 3.2 seconds

THAT is how you see which car is actually faster. That's why the Z06 runs 
faster 1/4 mile times when you remove the traction variable, because the 
Z06 is the faster car. The power to weight ratio should have told you that 
anyway, but you seem to be kind of dense.

You saying the alignment issue is "kinda bullshit" is almost unfathomably 
stupid. Are you calling FACTS "kinds bullshit" now? The alignment issue is 
something they discovered after the fact, after the tests, after it was all 
done. This is a fact, and it came from motor trend themselves. And then you 
saying a bad alignment wouldn't affect track times? Really?

Jesus fucking christ, GT-R apologists are really, really fucking stupid.
